title: Arli National Park
text:
Arli National Park, often called Arly, is a <a href="national%20park">national park</a> located in <a href="Tapoa%20Province">Tapoa Province</a>, southeastern <a href="Burkina%20Faso">Burkina Faso</a>. It adjoins <a href="Benin">Benin</a>'s <a href="Pendjari%20National%20Park">Pendjari National Park</a> in the south and the <a href="Singou%20Reserve">Singou Reserve</a> in the west.
Geography and history.
The park is set in with a wide variety of habitats, ranging from the gallery forests of the Arli and Pendjari rivers to savanna woodland and sandstone hills of the Gobnangou chain. It is home to around 200 <a href="African%20elephant">African elephant</a>s, 200 <a href="Hippopotamus">hippo</a>s and 100 <a href="West%20African%20lion">lion</a>s. There are also <a href="African%20buffalo">buffalo</a>es, <a href="baboon">baboon</a>s, red and green <a href="monkey">monkey</a>s, <a href="warthog">warthog</a>s, and various <a href="antelope">antelope</a>s, such as the western <a href="hartebeest">hartebeest</a> and <a href="roan%20antelope">roan antelope</a>. There are also <a href="bushbuck">bushbuck</a>s, <a href="duiker">duiker</a>s and <a href="waterbuck">waterbuck</a>.
The park can be accessed via the N19 highway via <a href="Diapaga">Diapaga</a> (in the dry season also via <a href="Pama%2C%20Burkina%20Faso">Pama</a>). Arli National Park has several pools, such as Tounga where there is a <a href="Depression%20%28geology%29">waterhole</a> and there are two pools which are often visited by up to twenty <a href="Hippopotamus">hippo</a>s.
The park was earlier a habitat for the <a href="West%20African%20wild%20dog">West African wild dog</a> ("Lycaon pictus manguensis"), although this canid is likely <a href="Local%20extinction">extirpated</a> from the local area due to an <a href="population%20growth">expanding human population</a>, and a lack of national protection.
